item.title: Monitor your Copilot declarative agents using TypeSpec and Application Insights
item.description: Monitor your Copilot declarative agents using TypeSpec and Application Insights The complete example is available on GitHub: https://github.com/FranckyC/copilot-pro-dev-samples/tree/main/samples/da-appinsights-plugin-typespec Why monitoring? For those developing and deploying Copilot declarative agents, you’re likely familiar with the challenge of obtaining meaningful usage metrics. Since agent development is inherently empirical and iterative—often involving several cycles of deployment and refinement—it is essential for business owners to understand how their agents are performing before and after deployment to end users.

item.title: Use the Microsoft Graph API as a Copilot plugin for a declarative agent
item.description: Recently, I came across an interesting use case building an HR agent allowing employees to ask common questions about company internal policies. These policies were made available to Copilot through a custom Graph Connector. However, during our tests, we realized for some questions, Copilot was struggling answering correctly even though answers were present in FAQ documents alongside the policy itself.

item.title: Hey Copilot, what about my metadata?
item.description: In this blog post, I wanted to share with you a use case I came across regarding my recent experience with Copilot Studio. DISCLAIMER I’m not an “AI expert” by any means, just a developer who consumes AI services which is not quite the same :D. IMPORTANT UPDATE (23/08/2024) I had the confirmation from Microsoft that custom Copilots built through Copilot Studio do not leverage the user or tenants semantic index.
